p: Climate change is known to pose risks to human health [ 1, 2]. Through rising temperature, increasing variability in precipitation, rising sea levels, and a growing number of extreme weather events, climate change will not only exacerbate existing human health problems, but also affect peopleâ€™s livelihoods and damage critical health infrastructure [ 1, 2]. As human behaviour is regarded as a primary cause of climate change [ 1, 2], modifying our behaviour has been confirmed as one of the efficient and low-cost methods to mitigate climate change [ 2, 3].
